sentence: E arnings and sales growth have slowed in recent quarters atMicrosoft ( MSFT ), but the market still seems excited about growth prospects ahead, particularly in its commercial cloud segment.
The company is in the middle of a transformation under new CEO Satya Nadella, from a PC company to a services and cloud company.
By all indications, Microsoft's makeover is on track.
Shares surged 15% during the week ended April 24 after the company reported adjusted profit of 62 cents, down 9% from a year ago but well above the Thomson Reuters consensus estimate of 51 cents.
Sales rose 6% to $21.7 billion.
Lackluster results on the surface, but Wall Street found a lot to like below the surface.
After a slow start, Microsoft's Surface tablet is doing well.
Sales rose 44% to $713 million, driven by the Surface 3 Pro model.
Surface is part of the company's Devices and Consumer group.
Overall, sales rose 8% to nearly $9 billion, helped by solid Office 365 growth and a 21% rise in Bing search advertising sales.
Commercial revenue rose 5% to nearly $12.8 billion.
Cloud sales jumped 106% and are now on an annualized run rate of $6.3 billion, or nearly $1.6 billion a quarter.
Microsoft recently set a goal of increasing annual revenue from its commercial cloud business to $30 billion.
In fiscal 2014, total revenue came in at $86.8 billion, up nearly 12% from 2013.
Earlier this month, Bloomberg reported that Microsoft was evaluating a bid forSalesforce.com ( CRM ), but no talks had taken place.
On Friday, CNBC reported that significant talks did take place, but the two sides couldn't agree on price.
Microsoft reportedly was willing to offer roughly $55 billion for the company.
Microsoft declared a dividend of 31 cents a share in March, giving it an annualized yield of 2.6%.
Its dividend growth rate of 20% puts it near the top of the heap among technology stocks tracked in the Dow.
